article.title: Theory of electromagnetic wave propagation in ferromagnetic Rashba conductor

multiple_choice_question.text: What optical phenomenon is depicted in Figure 1(a)?
What happens to the Poynting vector (S) in the presence of linear birefringence?
choices: It becomes parallel to the wave vector (q).
It rotates around the magnetization vector (M).
It is not parallel to the wave vector (q).

multiple_choice_question.text: In which configuration is the Faraday effect maximal?
choices: When the magnetization (M) and wave vector (q) are perpendicular.
When the magnetization (M) and wave vector (q) are parallel or anti-parallel.
When the wave vector (q) is zero.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the defining characteristic of the Cotton-Mouton effect?
choices: Rotation of the polarization vector (E) around the magnetization (M).
Magnetization-induced birefringence under the Voigt configuration (M⊥q).
Rotation of the polarization vector (E) around the wave vector (q).

multiple_choice_question.text: What type of directional dichroism is depicted in Figures 2(a,b)?
What is the key difference between Figures 2(a,b) and Figures 2(c,d)?
choices: The direction of the Poynting vector (S)

multiple_choice_question.text: What optical phenomenon occurs when Re(ε⊥) and Re(ε) have opposite signs?
In Figure 3(c), if the medium interface involves the z-axis, what optical phenomenon is observed?
What is the significance of α×M = 0 in Figures 4(a) and 4(b)?
choices: The Fermi surface and energy dispersion are asymmetric.
The Fermi surface and energy dispersion have rotation invariance around the αˆ-axis.
The band degeneracy is recovered at a Dirac point.
The light absorption depends on the direction of k⊥.

multiple_choice_question.text: What happens to the energy degeneracy when α×M ≠ 0?
choices: It is recovered at the Dirac point satisfying |k⊥ × α − M| = 0.
It becomes dependent on the direction of k.

multiple_choice_question.text: What effect is represented by the first term of Equation 111?
What is the significance of the Onsager relation in the context of Figure 6(b)?
choices: It describes the connection between the Edelstein and inverse Edelstein effects.
It explains the generation of the q-induced effective magnetic field Beff(q).
It governs the anisotropic property of the current response.
It dictates the rotation of the electric field (E) around Beff(q).

multiple_choice_question.text: What optical phenomenon is associated with the combined direct and inverse Edelstein effects with spatial dispersion?
What causes the Faraday rotation in a ferromagnetic Rashba conductor?
choices: The q-induced effective magnetic field Beff(q)
The toroidal moment Tˆ = αˆ × Mˆ

multiple_choice_question.text: What role does the "quadrupole" moment Q play in the optical response?
choices: It induces a rotation of the electric field (E) around q⊥, similar to natural optical activity.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the effect of the nonreciprocal current flow induced by the "toroidal" moment Tˆ and the perpendicular "quadrupole" moment Q⊥?
choices: It contributes to the anomalous Hall effect.
It generates a difference in absorption for counterpropagating electromagnetic waves.
